title: Tutorial
text: Gretool package implemented R publicly available https://github.com/thereallda/Gretool.

title: Tutorial
text: tutorial, demonstrate Gretool workflow using glyco-capped RNA-seq data human. start reading data, including count matrix metadata. metadata requires lease two columns: 1. condition column specifies biological group sample, .Input, indicating sample input sample biological condition . 2. enrich column denotes enrichment group sample, Input, representing input library. Also, information, batch group can included metadata. Next, use count matrix metadata create Gretool object. Gretool object serves container contains data (raw normalized counts data) analysis (e.g., normalization performance evaluation score enrichment results). constructing Gretool object, can provide following arguments: id input (input.id = "Input") enrichment (enrich.id = "Enrich"), enrich column metadata (required). Prefix spike-genes (spike..prefix = "^FB") (optional); id synthetic spike-(synthetic.id = c("Syn1", "Syn2")), row names counts_mat (optional);
code: library(Gretool) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(tidyr) library(patchwork)  # read in metadata and counts matrix counts_mat <- read.csv("data/Counts.csv", row.names = 1) meta <- read.csv("data/metadata.csv", comment.char = "#") head(meta) #>         id sample.id condition enrich replicate #> 1 H.input1  H.input1   H.Input  Input         1 #> 2 H.input2  H.input2   H.Input  Input         2 #> 3 H.input3  H.input3   H.Input  Input         3 #> 4 H.input4  H.input4   H.Input  Input         4 #> 5    H.ip1     H.ip1  H.Enrich Enrich         1 #> 6    H.ip2     H.ip2  H.Enrich Enrich         2 # rownames of metadata should be consistent with the colnames of counts_mat rownames(meta) <- meta$id # create object Gretool <- createGretool(data = counts_mat,                          col.data = meta,                          input.id = "Input",                          enrich.id = "Enrich"                          ) Gretool #> class: Gretool  #> dim: 62700 16  #> metadata(0): #> assays(1): '' #> rownames(62700): ENSG00000279928 ENSG00000228037 ... ENSG00000210195 #>   ENSG00000210196 #> rowData names(3): GeneID SpikeIn Synthetic #> colnames(16): H.input1 H.input2 ... T.ip3 T.ip4 #> colData names(7): id id.1 ... replicate batch

title: Tutorial
text: Gretool starts quality control step filter lowly-expressed genes. step performed FilterLowExprGene keeping genes least min.count least n samples. n determined smallest group sample size specifying group .
code: Gretool <- FilterLowExprGene(Gretool, group = Gretool$condition, min.count = 10) Gretool #> class: Gretool  #> dim: 15832 16  #> metadata(0): #> assays(1): '' #> rownames(15832): ENSG00000142611 ENSG00000157911 ... ENSG00000210195 #>   ENSG00000210196 #> rowData names(3): GeneID SpikeIn Synthetic #> colnames(16): H.input1 H.input2 ... T.ip3 T.ip4 #> colData names(7): id id.1 ... replicate batch

title: Tutorial
text: main Gretool function can used perform gene selection, normalization, evaluation. function return selected gene set rowData, normalized count matrix counts slot (return.norm=TRUE), normalization factors (norm_factors slot), evaluation metrics scores norm_metrics norm_scores slots, respectively. Detailed steps described bellow.
code: Gretool <- Gretool(Gretool,                 scaling.method = c( "TMM", "DESeq"),                ruv.norm = TRUE, ruv.k = 3,                eval.pam.k = 2:3, eval.pc.n = 3,                 return.norm = TRUE                ) #> Gene set selection for normalization and assessment... #> - The number of negative control genes for normalization: 1000  #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  #> - The number of positive evaluation genes: 500  #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  #> - The number of negative evaluation genes: 500  #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  #> Apply normalization... #> - Scaling...  #> - Regression-based normalization...  #> Perform assessment...

title: Tutorial
text: , use top-ranked procedure DESeq_RUVs_k3 downstream analysis. perform PCA based count matrix sample interest normalization, demonstrating effect normalization.
code: # get scores for normalization norm_scores <- getScore(Gretool)  head(norm_scores) #>               BIO_SIM EN_SIM BATCH_SIM PAM_SIM RLE_MED RLE_IQR WV_COR UV_COR #> DESeq_RUVs_k3      28     29         1      29      30      14     26     28 #> TMM_RUVs_k3        29     28         1      28      29      15     27     27 #> Raw_RUVs_k3        30     30         1      30       7      30     22     15 #> DESeq_RUVs_k2      27     22         1      27      28       8     23     16 #> TMM_RUVs_k2        26     19         1      26      27      13     20     11 #> TMM_RUVs_k1        23     14         1      20      24      25      9     20 #>                  SCORE #> DESeq_RUVs_k3 26.28571 #> TMM_RUVs_k3   26.14286 #> Raw_RUVs_k3   23.42857 #> DESeq_RUVs_k2 21.57143 #> TMM_RUVs_k2   20.28571 #> TMM_RUVs_k1   19.28571  # select normalization norm_method <- rownames(norm_scores[1,])  # get normalized counts norm_data <- Gretool::Counts(Gretool, slot = "sample", method = norm_method)  # get normalization factors norm_factors <- getFactor(Gretool, slot = "sample", method = norm_method)  # create sample name, e.g., A.Input.1 samples_name <- paste(Gretool$condition, Gretool$replicate, sep=".")  # PCA for raw count p1 <- PCAplot(Gretool::Counts(Gretool, slot="sample", "Raw"),              color = Gretool$condition,             shape = Gretool$enrich,             label = samples_name,              vst.norm = TRUE) +    ggtitle("Raw") #> Warning: `aes_string()` was deprecated in ggplot2 3.0.0. #> ℹ Please use tidy evaluation idioms with `aes()`. #> ℹ See also `vignette("ggplot2-in-packages")` for more information. #> ℹ The deprecated feature was likely used in the Gretool package. #>   Please report the issue to the authors. #> This warning is displayed once every 8 hours. #> Call `lifecycle::last_lifecycle_warnings()` to see where this warning was #> generated.  # PCA for normalized count p2 <- PCAplot(log1p(norm_data),              color = Gretool$condition,             shape = Gretool$enrich,             label = samples_name,              vst.norm = FALSE) +    ggtitle("After normalization")  # combine two plots p1 + p2

title: Tutorial
text: Gretool package can help find enrichment genes biological groups via differential expression. can identify genes significantly increased enrichment samples compared input samples. FindEnrichment automates processes groups provided condition column. default, enriched genes defined fold change normalized transcript counts ≥ 2 (logfc.cutoff = 1), FDR < 0.05 (p.cutoff = 0.05) enrichment samples compared input samples. Use getEnrichment retrieve list enrichment result tables. enrichment table data.frame list genes rows, associated information columns (GeneID, logFC, p-values, etc.). following columns present table: GeneID: ID genes. logFC: log2 fold-change enrichment input samples. Positive values indicate gene highly enriched enrichment group. logCPM: log2 CPM (counts per million) average expression samples. LR: Likelihood ratio likelihood ratio test. PValue: p-value likelihood ratio test. FDR: False discovery rate p-value, default “BH” method applied.
code: # find all enriched genes Gretool <- FindEnrichment(Gretool,                            slot="sample",                            norm.method = norm_method,                            logfc.cutoff = 1,                            p.cutoff = 0.05) #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  # get filtered enrichment results res.sig.ls <- getEnrichment(Gretool, slot="sample", filter=TRUE) names(res.sig.ls) <- c('H','T') # count number of enrichment in each group unlist(lapply(res.sig.ls, nrow)) #>    H    T  #> 1924 2023

title: Tutorial
text: can perform differential modification analysis DiffModification default, DiffModification output differential modification results genes. can subset table based enriched genes FindEnrichment can visualize differential results scatter plot
code: # create biological column in metadata meta$bio <- gsub('\\..*','',meta$condition) meta #>                id sample.id condition enrich replicate bio #> H.input1 H.input1  H.input1   H.Input  Input         1   H #> H.input2 H.input2  H.input2   H.Input  Input         2   H #> H.input3 H.input3  H.input3   H.Input  Input         3   H #> H.input4 H.input4  H.input4   H.Input  Input         4   H #> H.ip1       H.ip1     H.ip1  H.Enrich Enrich         1   H #> H.ip2       H.ip2     H.ip2  H.Enrich Enrich         2   H #> H.ip3       H.ip3     H.ip3  H.Enrich Enrich         3   H #> H.ip4       H.ip4     H.ip4  H.Enrich Enrich         4   H #> T.input1 T.input1  T.input1   T.Input  Input         1   T #> T.input2 T.input2  T.input2   T.Input  Input         2   T #> T.input3 T.input3  T.input3   T.Input  Input         3   T #> T.input4 T.input4  T.input4   T.Input  Input         4   T #> T.ip1       T.ip1     T.ip1  T.Enrich Enrich         1   T #> T.ip2       T.ip2     T.ip2  T.Enrich Enrich         2   T #> T.ip3       T.ip3     T.ip3  T.Enrich Enrich         3   T #> T.ip4       T.ip4     T.ip4  T.Enrich Enrich         4   T  # testing  diff_mod <- DiffModification(   Gretool,   norm.method = norm_method,   col.data = meta,   contrast.df = data.frame(Group1=c('H'),                             Group2=c('T')),   assay.colname = 'enrich',   biology.colname = 'bio',   input.id = 'Input',   enrich.id = 'Enrich',   eps = 1e-4,   shrink_lambda = 0 ) #> - Estimate dispersion & Fit GLM...  #> - Testing differential genes...  head(diff_mod[[1]]) #>            GeneID  H.logFC         H.FDR  T.logFC        T.FDR        LR #> 1 ENSG00000210196 3.369089 5.975863e-167 2.400430 3.665593e-92 1.8006983 #> 4 ENSG00000212402 8.407736  4.578186e-89 5.930855 3.613089e-50 0.8825648 #> 5 ENSG00000263934 3.226858  1.271129e-87 3.001821 3.209291e-81 2.4853247 #> 6 ENSG00000136159 2.221450  5.022980e-81 2.249885 2.194611e-89 0.6462647 #> 7 ENSG00000198786 2.528707  2.740577e-79 2.228075 1.809955e-62 0.1451544 #> 8 ENSG00000173214 1.661057  9.826775e-73 1.726249 5.285824e-65 0.9099521 #>      PValue   mod.FDR  logFC.diff mod.type #> 1 0.1796281 0.4170512  0.96865947       NS #> 4 0.3475002 0.5457629  2.47688160       NS #> 5 0.1149126 0.3478914  0.22503734       NS #> 6 0.4214513 0.5947956 -0.02843545       NS #> 7 0.7032096 0.7958550  0.30063236       NS #> 8 0.3401271 0.5406134 -0.06519206       NS enrich_ids <- unique(unlist(lapply(res.sig.ls, function(x) x$GeneID)))  diff_mod_enrich <- subset(diff_mod[[1]], GeneID %in% enrich_ids) dim(diff_mod_enrich) #> [1] 2599   10 typedf1 <- data.frame(table(diff_mod_enrich$mod.type)) %>%   mutate(label = paste0(Var1,' (n=',Freq,')'),          prop = round(100*Freq/sum(Freq),1))  ggplot(diff_mod_enrich, aes(T.logFC,H.logFC, color=mod.type)) +   geom_point(aes(size = -log10(mod.FDR)), alpha=0.8, shape=16, stroke=NA) +   theme_classic() +   theme(legend.position = 'right',         axis.text = element_text(color='black'),         plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))+   scale_color_manual(values=c("#A83C1E","#4F99B4","grey80"),                      labels=typedf1$label) +   labs(color='',         title='H vs T')

title: Authors and Citation
text: Li D (2026). Gretool: Glyco-capped RNA Epitranscriptomic analysis TOOL. R package version 1.0.0, https://thereallda.github.io/Gretool/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {Gretool: Glyco-capped RNA Epitranscriptomic analysis TOOL},   author = {Dean Li},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://thereallda.github.io/Gretool/}, }

title: Glyco-capped RNA Epitranscriptomic analysis TOOL
text: Gretool provides toolkit handle glyco-capped RNA sequencing data.

title: Glyco-capped RNA Epitranscriptomic analysis TOOL
text: can install development version Gretool GitHub : Tutorial can found https://thereallda.github.io/Gretool/
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thereallda/Gretool")

what: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
code: ApplyNormalization(   data,   scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),   ruv.norm = TRUE,   ruv.k = 1,   ruv.drop = 0,   control.idx = NULL,   sc.idx = NULL,   enrich.idx = NULL,   spike.in.prefix = NULL,   synthetic.id = NULL )

title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
text: data un-normalized count data matrix shape n x p, n number samples p number features. scaling.method Vector normalization methods applied data. Available methods : c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"). Select one multiple methods. default normalization methods applied. ruv.norm Whether perform RUV normalization. ruv.k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. ruv.drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input. control.idx Vector negative control genes RUV normalization. sc.idx numeric matrix specifying replicate samples compute count differences used estimate factors unwanted variation. enrich.idx Matrix two rows indicating column index enrichment input samples raw/normalized count data matrix. first row column index input second row column index enrichment samples. spike..prefix character specify prefix spike-id. synthetic.id Character vector string specifying name synthetic RNAs.

title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
text: List objects containing normalized data associated normalization factors.

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
code: AssessNormalization(   data.ls,   bio.group = NULL,   enrich.group = NULL,   batch.group = NULL,   eval.pam.k = 2:6,   eval.pc.n = 3,   log = TRUE,   pos.eval.set = NULL,   neg.eval.set = NULL )

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
text: data.ls List containing normalized counts adjust factors adjusting unwanted variation. Output ApplyNormalization. bio.group Vector index indicating column index samples biological groups raw/normalized count data matrix. enrich.group Vector index indicating column index enrichment input samples raw/normalized count data matrix. batch.group Vector index indicating column index batch groups raw/normalized count data matrix. eval.pam.k Integer vector integers indicates number clusters PAM clustering performance evaluation, default: 2:6. eval.pc.n Integer indicates evaluation metrics calculated first nth PCs, default: 3. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. pos.eval.set Vector genes id. neg.eval.set Vector genes id.

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
text: List containing metrics matrix ranking matrix, sorted score methods top bottom.

what: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
title: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
code: BetweenStatPlot(   data,   x,   y,   color,   palette = NULL,   test = c("wilcox.test", "t.test", "none"),   add.p = c("p", "p.adj"),   comparisons = NULL,   step.increase = 0.3,   title = NULL )

title: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
text: data data frame (tibble). x grouping variable data. y value variable data. color color variable data. palette color palette different groups. test Perform wilcoxon rank sum test t-test test, must one c("wilcox.test", "t.test", "none"). add.p Label p-value adjusted p-value, must one c("p", "p.adj"). comparisons list length-2 vectors specifying groups interest compared. example compare groups "" vs "B" "B" vs "C", argument follow: comparisons = list(c("", "B"), c("B", "C")) step.increase Numeric vector increase fraction total height every additional comparison minimize overlap. title Plot title, default NULL.

title: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
Accessor for counts — Counts
code: Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method)  Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method) <- value  # S4 method for class 'Gretool,character,character' Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method)  # S4 method for class 'Gretool,character,character,matrix' Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method) <- value

title: Accessor for counts — Counts
text: object Gretool. slot slot get, one sample spike_in. method counts matrix get, must one raw normalized counts matrix presented selected slot. value Raw normalized counts matrix.

what: Create a matrix for RUVSeq — CreateGroupMatrix
title: Create a matrix for RUVSeq — CreateGroupMatrix
Create a matrix for RUVSeq — CreateGroupMatrix
code: CreateGroupMatrix(group.vec)

title: Create a matrix for RUVSeq — CreateGroupMatrix
Create a matrix for RUVSeq — CreateGroupMatrix
Create a matrix for RUVSeq — CreateGroupMatrix

what: Differential modification by linear model test — DiffModification
title: Differential modification by linear model test — DiffModification
Differential modification by linear model test — DiffModification
code: DiffModification(   object,   col.data,   contrast.df,   norm.method = NULL,   test.gene.id = NULL,   assay.colname = "assay",   biology.colname = "bio",   input.id = "Input",   enrich.id = "Enrich",   norm = FALSE,   adjust = TRUE,   p.cutoff = 0.05,   pseudo.count = 0.125,   eps = 1e-04,   shrink_lambda = 0 )

title: Differential modification by linear model test — DiffModification
text: object  col.data data.frame least three columns (indicate condition, enrich biological groups). Rows col.data correspond columns data. contrast.df Data frame contrast, extracting results first column vs. second column. norm.method Normalization methods use test.gene.id List gene ids tested assay.colname Name assay column col.data, e.g., "enrich". biology.colname Name biological column col.data, e.g., "bio". input.id Input library id, must consistent enrich column col.data, e.g., "Input". enrich.id Enrich library id, must consistent enrich column col.data, e.g., "Enrich". adjust Whether perform adjustment based input expression levels. p.cutoff P values Cutoff significant differential modification genes. pseudo.count Minimal offset prevent negative values. eps Threshold prevent negative values, default: 1e-4 shrink_lambda Factor control shrinkage expression size factor input, default: 0.

title: Differential modification by linear model test — DiffModification
Dot-plot with mean_sd bar — DotPlot
code: DotPlot(data, x, y, fill = NULL, palette = NULL)

title: Dot-plot with mean_sd bar — DotPlot
text: data data.frame (tibble). x grouping variable data. y value variable data. fill fill variable data. palette fill palette different groups.

title: Filter Low Expressed Genes — FilterLowExprGene
code: FilterLowExprGene(x, group = NULL, min.count = 10)

title: Filter Low Expressed Genes — FilterLowExprGene
text: x Input data, can counts matrix object. group Vector factor giving group membership oneway layout, appropriate, default: NULL. min.count Minimum count required least samples, default: 10.

what: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
title: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
text: Find enriched genes enrich input samples

title: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
code: FindEnrichment(   object,   slot = c("sample", "spike_in"),   norm.method,   logfc.cutoff = 1,   p.cutoff = 0.05,   only.pos = TRUE,   ... )

title: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
text: object object. slot slot, one sample spike_in. norm.method normalization method use differential analysis, must one methods presented selected slot. logfc.cutoff Filter genes least X-fold difference (log2-scale) two groups samples, default: 1. p.cutoff Filter genes p.cutoff adjusted p-value, default: 0.05. .pos Whether significant differential genes consider genes positive fold-change. ... Additional parameters can passed edgeRDE.

title: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
Gene set selection — GeneSelection
text: Select negative control genes RUV normalization, positive negative evaluation genes assessment.

title: Gene set selection — GeneSelection
code: GeneSelection(object, n.neg.control = 1000, n.pos.eval = 500, n.neg.eval = 500)

title: Gene set selection — GeneSelection
text: object Gretool object n.neg.control Number negative control genes RUV normalization, default: 1000. n.pos.eval Number positive evaluation genes wanted variation assessment, default: 500. n.neg.eval Number negative evaluation genes unwanted variation assessment, default: 500.

title: Normalization and assessment — Gretool
code: Gretool(   object,   auto = TRUE,   return.norm = FALSE,   n.neg.control = 1000,   n.pos.eval = 500,   n.neg.eval = 500,   neg.control = NULL,   pos.eval = NULL,   neg.eval = NULL,   scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),   ruv.norm = TRUE,   ruv.k = 1,   ruv.drop = 0,   eval.pam.k = 2:6,   eval.pc.n = 3 )

title: Normalization and assessment — Gretool
text: object Gretool object. auto Whether automatically select negative control, positive evaluation negative evaluation genes, default: TRUE. return.norm Whether return normalized counts object. default, return normalized counts reducing memory costs. n.neg.control Number negative control genes RUV normalization, default: 1000. n.pos.eval Number positive evaluation genes wanted variation assessment, default: 500. n.neg.eval Number negative evaluation genes unwanted variation assessment, default: 500. neg.control Vector negative control genes' id RUV normalization, default: NULL. pos.eval Vector positive evaluation genes' id wanted variation assessment, default: NULL. neg.eval Vector negative evaluation genes' id unwanted variation assessment, default: NULL. scaling.method Vector scaling methods applied data. Available methods : c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"). Select one multiple methods. default scaling methods applied. ruv.norm Whether perform RUV normalization. ruv.k number factors unwanted variation estimated data, default: 1. ruv.drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default: 0. eval.pam.k Integer vector integers indicates number clusters PAM clustering performance evaluation, default: 2:6. eval.pc.n Integer indicates evaluation metrics calculated first nth PCs, default: 3.

code: OutlierTest(x, return = FALSE, remove = FALSE)

text: x object return Whether return object simply perform test, default FALSE remove Whether remove outliers. TRUE, must paired "return=TRUE", default: FALSE

title: Esimate sequencing depth — PS.Est.Depth
code: PS.Est.Depth(n, iter = 5, ct.sum = 5, ct.mean = 0.5)

title: Esimate sequencing depth — PS.Est.Depth
text: n data matrix. rows counts gene, columns counts experiment. iter Number iterations used. Default value: 5. default value usually good choice. ct.sum total number reads gene across experiments <= ct.sum, gene considered estimating sequencing depth. Default value: 5. ct.mean mean number reads gene across experiments <= ct.mean, gene considered estimating sequencing depth. Default value: 0.5.

Gretool object and constructor — Gretool-class
text: Gretool object extends SummarizedExperiment class. createGretool easy constructor Gretool object

title: Gretool object and constructor — Gretool-class
code: createGretool(   data,   col.data,   spike.in.prefix = NULL,   input.id = "Input",   enrich.id = "Enrich",   synthetic.id = NULL )

title: Gretool object and constructor — Gretool-class
text: data un-normalized count data matrix shape n x p, n number samples p number features. col.data data.frame least two columns (indicate condition enrich groups). Rows col.data correspond columns data. spike..prefix character specify prefix spike-id, e.g., "^FB" stands fly spike-id, default: NULL. input.id Input library id, must consistent enrich column col.data, e.g., "Input". enrich.id Enrich library id, must consistent enrich column col.data, e.g., "Enrich". synthetic.id Vector synthetic RNA id, e.g. c("Syn1","Syn2"), default: NULL.

title: Gretool object and constructor — Gretool-class
text: Description slot: assay SummarizedExperiment::Assays object, contains counts. counts list holding raw/normalized counts sample spike_in. norm_factors list holding normalization factors sample spike_in. norm_metrics data frame normalization methods row metrics columns. norm_score data frame normalization methods row scores columns. enrichment list holding differential analysis results. enrichment_filtered lists holding filtered differential analysis results. parameter list parameters.

Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
code: edgeRDE(   counts,   group,   norm.factors = NULL,   adjust.factors = NULL,   design.formula = NULL,   contrast.df = NULL,   coef = NULL,   logfc.cutoff = 1,   p.cutoff = 0.05,   prior.count = 0.125,   only.pos = TRUE )

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
text: counts un-normalized counts data matrix. group Vector length p mapping columns counts corresponding samples group. norm.factors Vector normalization factors p length. adjust.factors Matrix column indicates adjusting factors estimated RUV. design.formula Formula contrast.df Data frame contrast, extracting results first column vs. second column. coef Integer character vector indicating coefficients linear model tested equal zero. Values must columns column names design. logfc.cutoff Filter genes least X-fold difference (log2-scale) two groups samples, default: 1. p.cutoff Filter genes Y adjusted p-value, default: 0.05. prior.count Average prior count added observation shrink estimated log-fold-changes towards zero, default: 0.125. .pos return positive genes filtered results res.sig.ls, default: TRUE.

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
text: List containing differential analysis object, result table filtered result table.

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: object counts matrix. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. tolerance Tolerance selection number positive singular values, .e., singular value must larger tolerance considered positive. control.idx ID control genes. sc.idx numeric matrix specifying replicate samples compute count differences used estimate factors unwanted variation (see details). drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: row sc.idx correspond set replicate samples. number columns size largest set replicates; rows smaller sets padded -1 values. example, sets replicate samples (1,2,3),(4,5),(6,7,8), scIdx 1 2 3 4 5 -1 6 7 8
